fields.Transcription:
Ako si June Norberte, galing ako sa Tuguegarao, Cagayan. Ahhh mejo mahirap ang pag punta ko dito sa America, syempre madaming gastos kapag pumunta ka dito sa America. Pag nandito ako sa America natulog pa ako sa Subway nang dalawang linggo" kase wala akong kilalang tao dito sa America bale mayroon akong nakilala dalawang babae doon sa subway restaurant. Nakilala ko sila dahil sa isang waitress doon at pinakilala ako at pumunta ako sa bahay nila at noong nandun na ako sa bahay nila syempre wala akong trabaho kaya nakitira muna ako doon ng tatlong buwan pagkatapos... ahhh syempre binibigyan nila ako ng perang pang gastos. After three months na nasa kanila ako mejo naka hanap narin ako ng trabaho na yun naka hanap ng trabaho doon sa dunkin donut eheh! So mahirap ang pumunta dito sa isang estrangharo na walang kilala dito sa america. Isa na experience ko na pumunta dito sa america kaya kwan.... Ang naging tahanan ko noon bilang primero dun sa yankers, nag stay ako doon ng 6 months pagkatapos meron akong nakilala sa Brongs/Bronx, isang pilipino rin na mayroong trabaho rin sa Laundry Mat kaya nagtrabaho na rin ako sa Laundry Mat kaya mahirap talaga yung pinanggalingan ko dito sa America. Pagkatapos eh... Halos isang taon rin ako nagtratrabaho sa Laundry Mat dun sa Bronx/brongs. Ngayon, may nakilala akong Italiano. Isang Italiano ehh na kung gustu ko magtrabaho sa kanya. Doon na nagsimula yung trabaho kong (jelly" delly") dun sa coop city doon sa Bronx/Brongs simula nun nasa kanya na ako, maganda yung ipina pakita niya sa akin. Linalabas niya ako pumupunta kami para mamasyal. Pina pasyal niya ako hanggang sa ipinakilala ulit ako sa isang Italiano na isa kaya sabi niya sa matanda eto si anu June sabi niya ehh mabuti itong tao sabi niya, kaya kung gusto mo kunin mo sa trabaho sabi niya sa akin.

I am June Norberte. I am from Tuguegarao, Cagayan. Moving here to America was a bit difficult for me. Of course, you have to spend a lot to get here in the United States. When I got here, I had to sleep at a Subway for two weeks because I didn't know anyone here. I met two women here who I knew through a mutual acquaintance who introduced us. Because I was unemployed, they let me stay at their place for 3 months. They even gave me cash to spend for basic needs. After those 3 months, I was able to get a job at a Dunkin Donuts. Moving here is hard for someone who like me who didn't know anyone. I also moved to Yonkers, I stayed there for 6 months, then I met someone in the Bronx, a fellow Filipino who works at a laundromat, and he helped me get a job in the same place. Getting to where I am now here in America was difficult.

I worked at the laundromat in the Bronx for almost 1 year. Then I met an Italian friend, an Italian friend who offered me work in case I needed it. That's when I started working at (his deli), also in the Bronx. Ever since then I've been working for him. He would treat me nicely, and he even took me out to go sightseeing around the City, he then introduced me to his fellow Italian, telling him "this is June", he said "he is a good person, so if you need good help you can hire him to work for you. ---I think thats good.... 8:20 Ako si June Norberte, galing ako sa Tuguegarao, Cagayan. Ang salita namin doon ay Ilocano at Itawis.

I am June Norberte, I am from Tuguegarao, Cagayan. The languages we have there are Ilocano and Itawis. 8:32 Ako si June Norberte at ang salita namin doon sa Cagayan Tuguegarao ay Ilocano at Itawis. 
 I am June Norberte and the languages we speak there in Cagayan- Tuguegarao, are Ilocano and Itaiws.
12:06 Ako si June Norberte galing ako sa Tuguegarao, Cagayan. Ang salita namin ay Ilocano at Itawis.

I am June Norberte, I am from Tuguegarao, Cagayan, The languages we speak are Ilocano and Itawis. 13:55 Ako si June Norberte taga Tuguegarao, Cagayan. Ang salita namin doon ay Ilocano at Itawis.

I am June Norberte, from Tuguegarao, Cagayan. The languages we speak there are Ilocano and Itawis. 14:22 Ako si June Norberte, galing ako sa Tuguegarao, Cagayan at ang salita namin ay Ilocano at Itawis meron pang isang salita cebuano didtu ako nag eskwela sa Davao City...(cebuano)  

I am June Norberte. I am from Tuguegarao, Cagayan, and (there) we speak Ilocano and Itawis, we also speak Cebuano, I went to school in Davao City. (This part is in Cebuano/Bisaya)
fields.Video Description:
This video was recorded by Jose Antonio Gerundio Piscano and Daniel Bogre Udell in New York City, United States. Ilocano is primarily spoken in Luzon, the Philippines, with scattered communities in the US states of Hawaii and California. It is considered the third most popular native language of the Philippines. It is closely related to Balangao language--the two are nearly mutually intelligible--as well as the eastern dialects of the Bontoc language. Ilocano developed its own writing system known as kur-itan which has since fallen out of use, although there are proposals to revive it as a script for instruction in public and private schools, as well as a UC Berkeley proposal to encode it in Unicode. The Province of La Union recognized Ilocano in 2012 as an official and national language of the Philippines, and was the first province in the Philippines to pass an ordinance protecting a native language.

Ilocano is spoken by a little over 7 million people internationally and is a Malayo-Polynesian language within the Austronesian language family.
Demographics: 6,920,000 in Philippines (2000 census). Population total all countries: 7,016,400.
YouTube License Statement: This video is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. To download a copy, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
fields.Geneaology: "[ Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Philippine, Northern Luzon, Ilocano ]"
